questions.text: There is an outbreak of acute encephalitis in the community and a vaccination drive is launched. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Killed and intramuscular.

Explanation:

  • Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is the most common cause of viral encephalitis outbreaks in endemic regions.
  • The Japanese Encephalitis vaccine (JE vaccine) is available in two types: inactivated (killed) and live attenuated.
  • The inactivated (killed) vaccine is commonly given intramuscularly (IM) as part of mass vaccination programs in outbreak settings.
  • Live attenuated vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are administered subcutaneously (SC), but they are generally used for routine immunization rather than in acute outbreak settings.

Types of Japanese Encephalitis Vaccines

Vaccine Type

Examples

Route of Administration

Usage

Inactivated (Killed)

JEEV, IXIARO

Intramuscular (IM)

Used in outbreaks & travelers

Live Attenuated

SA 14-14-2

Subcutaneous (SC)

Routine immunization

 

Live and subcutaneous (Option B): Incorrect. Although there is a live attenuated JE vaccine (e.g., SA 14-14-2), it is usually administered subcutaneously, not intramuscularly. However, this option does not align with standard killed vaccines used in most vaccination drives.

Live and intramuscular (Option C): Incorrect. Live attenuated vaccines for JE are administered subcutaneously, not intramuscularly.

Killed and subcutaneous (Option D): Incorrect. Killed vaccines are administered intramuscularly, not subcutaneously.

questions.text:
Which of the following regarding the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) is true?

 

1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.

2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.

3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine

4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.

5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is an acceptable range.

6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option B)

Explanation

1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
This is true. VVM is a tool used in primary healthcare to monitor the exposure of vaccines to heat during transportation and storage. It is particularly useful in areas with unreliable cold chain systems.

 

2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
This is also true. The VVM works by showing the cumulative amount of heat the vaccine has been exposed to, indicating whether the vaccine has been subjected to conditions that might reduce its efficacy.


 

3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine.
This is false. The VVM does not directly assess the efficacy of the vaccine. It only shows whether the vaccine has been exposed to heat beyond its acceptable limit, which might affect its effectiveness.

 

4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
This is false. The VVM does not calculate the expiry date of the vaccine. It is used to monitor heat exposure, not to predict or calculate the expiry date.

 

5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range.
This is false. The VVM cannot be used to relax the expiry date of a vaccine. If the vaccine has been exposed to temperatures beyond the recommended limit, its efficacy may be compromised regardless of its expiration date.

 

6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
This is false. When the square and circle on the VVM are the same color, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to heat for too long and should not be used, as it may have lost its potency.

questions.text:
A child presents with a dog bite from a street dog. On examination, an abrasion of 1.5 cm is present, with slight oozing. Which of the following statements is correct?

1. Category 3 wound

2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes

3. Clean the wound with spirit

4. Loose suturing of the wound with a proper dressing

5. Equine immunoglobulin is given a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice

6. The intradermal vaccine is administered on day 0,3,7,28
questions.solution:
1. Category 3 wound (1):
    • The wound involves an abrasion with oozing, which qualifies as a Category 3 exposure as per WHO guidelines. This category includes single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, contamination of mucous membranes with saliva, and exposure to broken skin.
  2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes (2):
    • Immediate and thorough washing of the wound with soap and water for 15–20 minutes is a key step in rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). It significantly reduces the viral load at the site.
  3. Clean the wound with spirit (3):
    • This is correct. After washing and drying the wound, disinfectants like povidone-iodine and spirit can be applied.
  4. Loose suturing of the wound with proper dressing (4):
    • Suturing is avoided in rabies-prone wounds unless absolutely necessary. If required, it is done only after administering rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound.
  5. Equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG) dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice (5):
    • ERIG is administered in Category 3 wounds at a dose of 40 IU/kg body weight. It is infiltrated locally around the wound as much as anatomically possible, with the remaining dose given intramuscularly, only once.
  6. Intradermal vaccine schedule: Days 0, 3, 7, 28 (6):
    • The child should receive the intradermal rabies vaccine on this schedule as part of PEP for a Category 3 wound.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

  • Option A (2, 3, 5, 6): Cleaning the wound with spirit (3) is incorrect.
  • Option C (1, 2, 3, 5): Cleaning with spirit (3) is incorrect, and the vaccine schedule is missing (6).
  • Option D (1, 2, 3, 6): Cleaning with spirit (3) is incorrect, and RIG (5) is omitted.

questions.text: Which of these vaccines do not follow open vial policy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Measles

  • Measles vaccine do not follow open vial policy

Open vial policy

  • States that “vaccine vials, once opened, can be reused in subsequent sessions for up to 28 days, provided that they are maintained in appropriate cold chain conditions to reduce the wastage of vaccines.
  • All liquid vaccines follow open-vial policies.
    • Eg: Hepatitis B, DPT, Pentavalent, OPV, IPV, PCV, Td.
  • Reconstituted vaccines such as MMR, BCG, JE, Yellow fever vaccine along with Rotavirus vaccine do not follow open vial policy

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial step when an immunization survey is being conducted?

choices.text: Completing the cluster and summary forms
Calculating the total fertility rate of the area

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Cluster identification

  • The initial step in conducting an immunization survey is Cluster identification.

The major steps of an immunization survey are as follows:

  • Planning the survey by finding the clusters and deciding how many interviewers are required.
  • To conduct the survey in which the interviewers visit houses and get information on the immunization status of the clusters (Option B)
  • To tabulate the data by completing the cluster and the summary forms (Option C)
  • To analyse the data which helps in evaluating the immunization status and the reasons for the failure of immunization.
  • To take action on the reports made by evaluating the data.

Calculating the total fertility rate of the area (Option D): This is not typically part of an immunization survey; it is more relevant to demographic studies.

questions.text: Which vaccine among the options exhibits a seroconversion rate that is quicker than the incubation period of the corresponding disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Measles:

  • Amongst the above options, measles vaccine has a faster seroconversion rate as compared to the incubation period of the disease and this is why measles vaccine is given when a disaster or an epidemic occurs.

Seroconversion:

  • is the transition from the point of viral infection to when antibodies of the virus become present in the blood.
  • Seroconversion rates are one of the methods used for determining the efficacy of a vaccine.
    • The higher the rate of seroconversion, the more protective the vaccine for a greater proportion of the population.
    • Seroconversion does not inherently confer immunity or resistance to infection.
    • Only some antibodies, such as anti-spike antibodies for COVID-19, confer protection.

Coronavirus (Option A): The coronavirus vaccine has almost the same seroconversion rate as compared to the incubation period of the disease.

Polio (Option C): The seroconversion rate of the polio vaccine is slower than its incubation period.

Mumps (Option D): The mumps vaccine has a slower seroconversion rate than its incubation period.

questions.text: In the market, there are several new vaccines being researched, and their effectiveness is being evaluated and displayed in the image provided. Which of the recently developed vaccines demonstrate comparable efficacy to the previous vaccine?
questions.solution:
• Option C is correct because vaccines C, D, and E show comparable efficacy to the previous vaccine.
  • Conclusion based on forest plot, comparing efficacies.
  • Confidence intervals overlap, indicating similar efficacy.

D only (Option A): Only includes plot D, neglecting C and E.

 

D and E (Option B): Only includes plots D and E, neglecting C.

 

A, B, C and D (Option D): Includes plots A and B, which differ significantly from efficacy zone, unlike C, D, and E.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not recommended after 65 years?
questions.solution:
• HPV vaccine is not routinely recommended after 26 years and is generally not given after 45 years, as older individuals are less likely to benefit.
  • Influenza, Pneumococcal, and Herpes Zoster vaccines are strongly recommended for adults ≥65 years to prevent severe infections.
  • HPV vaccination is primarily for younger individuals to prevent cervical and other HPV-related cancers.
  • Older adults have likely been exposed to HPV already, reducing vaccine efficacy.

Adult Vaccination Recommendations (≥65 Years)

Aging individuals face an increased risk of respiratory infections, viral reactivation, and opportunistic infections due to immune decline. Vaccination is a critical preventive strategy.

Recommended Vaccines for Adults ≥65 Years

Vaccine

Purpose

Recommended After 65?

Influenza

Prevents seasonal flu complications

Yes, annually

Pneumococcal (PCV15/PCV20, PPSV23)

Prevents pneumonia, bacteremia, meningitis

Yes, once or as per schedule

Herpes Zoster (Recombinant Zoster Vaccine - RZV)

Prevents shingles and postherpetic neuralgia

Yes, 2 doses after 50 years

Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis (Tdap/Td)

Prevents tetanus and pertussis

Yes, booster every 10 years

COVID-19

Reduces risk of severe COVID-19

Yes, as per updated recommendations

HPV

Prevents cervical and other cancers

Not recommended after 45 years

Why is the HPV Vaccine Not Given After 65?

  • Most individuals are already exposed to HPV by this age.
  • Vaccine efficacy is highest in younger populations (9-26 years).
  • No added benefit in older adults, as HPV-related cancer risk decreases.

Influenza (Option A): Incorrect because annual flu vaccination is recommended to prevent severe complications.

 

Herpes Zoster (Option B): Incorrect because shingles risk increases with age, so vaccination is advised after 50 years.

 

Pneumococcal (Option C): Incorrect because pneumococcal vaccine is recommended after 65 years to prevent pneumonia and invasive infections.

questions.text: Considering the immune status of a girl child who has been experiencing repeated yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since the age of 3 months, which vaccine should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Measles/MMR

Explanation:

  • Measles/MMR should be avoided due to the live virus components, which can be risky for immunocompromised children.
  • A child who has a history of repeated yeast infections and respiratory viral infections may have an underlying immune deficiency or immunodeficiency disorder.
  • Immunocompromised children, particularly those with T-cell deficiency (such as in conditions like DiGeorge syndrome or severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)), should avoid live vaccines due to the risk of severe infection.
  • The Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine contains live attenuated viruses for measles, mumps, and rubella. In immunocompromised children, live vaccines pose a risk of causing active infections or serious complications due to their weakened immune system.

National Immunization Schedule (India)

Vaccine

Killed IPV (Option A): The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) contains inactivated (killed) virus, which is safe for immunocompromised children because it cannot cause infection.

DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus) (Option C): The DPT vaccine is an inactivated vaccine and is safe for immunocompromised children.

TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid) (Option D): This is a toxoid vaccine and is also safe for immunocompromised children, as it does not contain live bacteria.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program for a 10- year-old student in school?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) TT/ Td

Explanation:

  • According to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) of India, children at the age of 10 years receive the Td vaccine (Tetanus and Diphtheria, previously TT). This booster dose maintains immunity provided by earlier doses given during infancy and early childhood.

DPT (Option D): Used for children below 7 years. Beyond this age, the Td vaccine replaces DPT to minimize side effects from higher diphtheria toxoid content.

questions.text: Which of the options listed below indicates the degree of heat resistance exhibited by vaccines?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) VVM

Explanation:

  • The Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) is used to indicate the degree of heat resistance and the extent to which a vaccine has been exposed to heat. It is a color-changing indicator attached to vaccine vials to help assess whether a vaccine has been stored or transported at the correct temperature. This helps in determining if a vaccine remains safe and effective for use.

 

VMV (Option A): There is no known vaccine-related term called VMV.

MVV (Option C): This is not a recognized term related to vaccine heat resistance.

VMM (Option D): This also is not related to heat resistance in vaccines.

questions.text: Vaccine protocol followed after Disaster?

choices.text: Only the health worker given cholera, typhoid, tetanus toxoid

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Only the health worker given cholera, typhoid, tetanus toxoid

  • Health workers receive additional protection in disaster situations
  • Cholera, typhoid, and tetanus toxoid vaccinations provided to minimize infection risk
  • Ensures safety while providing medical care

 

Vaccination protocol post- disaster :

  • All vaccines except for measles are contraindicated post-disaster.
  • Multidose vaccines, such as typhoid and cholera vaccines, have poor compliance and have not yet proven to be effective as a large-scale public health measure.
  • The most common post-disaster outbreak is measles. For this reason, measles vaccines can be given within three days of exposure since the time taken for antibodies to form is less than the natural incubation period of the disease.
  • Tetanus vaccine is given based on previous vaccinations and severity of injury.
  • Vaccines for healthcare workers: Cholera, Typhoid, Tetanus, Hep B.

 

Everyone is given diphtheria (Option A): Diphtheria vaccination likely already part of routine immunization schedules

Everyone is given tetanus toxoid (Option B): Tetanus toxoid crucial in disaster scenarios, especially for those with injuries

Everyone is given cholera vaccine (Option C): Cholera vaccination not typically administered to everyone in general disaster response

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in a child with immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella):

Explanation:

  • MMR is a live attenuated vaccine and is generally contraindicated in immunocompromised individuals, whereas Hepatitis B, DPT, and IPV are inactivated vaccines and are considered safe for them.

Category

Recommendations

HIV+ Individuals
  • Inactivated Vaccines: Most are recommended, but effectiveness may vary based on immune deficiency.
  • Live Vaccines: Generally contraindicated, with exceptions:
    • MMR: Administer if asymptomatic or with mild symptoms (CD4+ ≥ 15%).
    • Varicella: Consider if CD4+ ≥ 15%; MMRV is not recommended.
    • Yellow Fever: Contraindicated for severely immunocompromised under 6; specific precautions for others.
  • Other Vaccines:
    • Pneumococcal: PCV13 and PPSV23 are recommended.
    • Meningococcal: MCV4 is recommended for children ≥ 2 months.
    • Hib: Recommended if not given during infancy.

Immunocompromised
  • General Principles: Vaccination varies by condition, severity, risk, and vaccine type.
  • Live Vaccines: Typically contraindicated; exceptions based on condition and vaccine. (Option C)
  • Inactivated Vaccines: Effective but may be reduced based on immune deficiency. (Option A, B, D ruled out)

Preterm Infants
  • General Recommendations: Vaccinate based on chronological age, similar to full-term infants.
  • Hepatitis B Vaccine:
    • For ≥ 2 kg and stable: Birth dose within 24 hours.
    • For < 2 kg: Birth dose deferred until 1 month or hospital discharge (if HBsAg-negative mother). All preterm, low-birthweight infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers should receive HBIG and hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth, with three additional doses starting at 1 month.

Vaccination in elderly
  • Influenza (flu): Annual vaccination, especially with high-dose or adjuvanted vaccines, helps protect against flu complications such as pneumonia and organ failure.
  • Pneumococcal vaccine: A one-time vaccine against bacterial infections that can cause severe pneumonia.
  • Shingles: A two-dose series to prevent shingles and its complications, like postherpetic neuralgia.
  • Tdap (Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis): Booster shots every 10 years to maintain immunity.
  • RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus): Newly approved for older adults, especially those with heart or lung conditions.

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-month-old baby, concerned that no BCG scar has appeared, although the baby received the BCG vaccine at birth. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Do the Mantoux test & wait for the result
Refer the baby for a chest X-ray & further evaluation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Reassure the mother

Explanation:

  • After BCG vaccination, some children may not develop a visible scar, even though they have adequate immunity. No BCG scar is not an indication for revaccination if the child is otherwise healthy. WHO and national immunization guidelines recommend no further action in such cases- simply reassure the caregiver.

BCG Vaccine

  • Type: Live attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis
  • Schedule: Single dose at birth (or as early as possible till 1 year of age)
  • Dose & route: 0.05 mL (infants <1 yr), 0.1 mL (≥1 yr) — intradermal, left upper arm
  • Purpose: Protection against severe forms of childhood TB (TB meningitis, miliary TB)
  • Contraindications: Symptomatic HIV infection, immunodeficiency, pregnancy, generalized skin disease
  • Storage: Lyophilized form at 2–8 °C; reconstituted vaccine stable for 3–4 hours only
  • Adverse events: Local ulcer at site, regional lymphadenitis, keloid (rare)
  • Coverage target: Universal Immunization Programme (UIP)

Give the BCG vaccine immediately (Option B): Revaccination is not recommended; lack of scar doesn’t mean lack of immunity.

Do Mantoux test & wait for the result (Option C): Not required in an asymptomatic, healthy, vaccinated child.

Refer for chest X-ray & further evaluation (Option D): Only indicated if there are clinical features suggestive of TB.

questions.text: Out of the MR & Pentavalent vaccine, which can be reused, and which one should be discarded when the vial is opened according to the open vial policy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Discard MR, reuse Pentavalent

Explanation:

Open Vial Policy (WHO guidelines) allows certain multi-dose vials to be reused for up to 28 days after opening if:

  • They have no preservative contamination.
  • They are kept under proper cold chain conditions (2–8 °C).

Pentavalent vaccine → liquid formulation with preservative → can be reused until expiry within the 28-day rule.

MR (Measles-Rubella) vaccine → lyophilized (freeze-dried) powder without preservative, reconstituted with diluent before use → must be discarded within 4 hours of reconstitution, irrespective of remaining doses.

Open Vial Policy:

  • Allows certain vaccines to be used in multiple immunization sessions after opening the vial, if stored and handled properly. If the vaccine is under the open vial policy then VVM will bw on the body (not on cap/neck).

Purpose:

  • Reduce vaccine wastage
  • Ensure uninterrupted immunization services
  • Lower programme costs without compromising safety.

The vaccine can be kept and used for up to 28 days after opening only if:

  • Vaccine is WHO-prequalified for MDVP use
  • Vaccine vial is kept at recommended storage temperature (+2°C to +8°C)
  • VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor) has not crossed discard point
  • Expiry date has not passed
  • Aseptic technique used every time vial is opened
  • Reconstituted vaccines (like BCG, Measles, MR, JE) must be discarded within 6 hours or at the end of the session — no exception.

Vaccines NOT under Open Vial Policy:

  • BCG
  • Measles / MR
  • COVID 19 (use within 8 hours)

Discard Pentavalent, reuse MR (Option B): Wrong - MR cannot be used after 4 hous of reconstitution, so it must be discarded.

Discard both MR and Pentavalent (Option C): Wrong - Pentavalent can be reused if stored properly.

Reuse both MR and Pentavalent (Option D): Wrong - MR cannot be reused after 4 hours of reconstitution.

questions.text: A person has recently moved from Nigeria to the United States. Which of the following vaccines is required for international travel from Nigeria to the USA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Yellow Fever (17D) vaccine

Explanation:

  • Yellow fever is endemic in several African countries, including Nigeria. The WHO’s International Health Regulations require travelers from countries with risk of yellow fever transmission to present a valid yellow fever vaccination certificate when entering certain countries, including the USA. This prevents international spread of the disease.

Yellow Fever (17D) vaccine is a live-attenuated viral vaccine.

  • Single subcutaneous dose provides immunity for life
  • Required for travel from yellow fever-endemic areas to prevent spread to countries where the disease is not endemic.
  • Nigeria is a yellow fever endemic zone; hence proof of vaccination is mandatory.
  • Must be given at least 10 days before travel to be valid.
  • Contraindications: Infants <9 months, severe egg allergy, immunocompromised persons, pregnancy (relative).

Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccine (Option B): Recommended for travelers to rural Asia-Pacific regions, not Nigeria–USA travel.

Measles vaccine (Option C): Important for general immunization but not an international travel requirement between Nigeria and USA.

Rabies vaccine (Option D): Given for post-exposure prophylaxis or pre-exposure for high-risk groups, not a routine travel requirement for this route.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines will you use in the clinic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Use A and B:

Explanation:

Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM):

  • Purpose:
    • A heat-sensitive label on vaccine vials to ensure vaccine potency during transportation and storage.
  • Function:
    • The VVM contains a heat-sensitive material that changes colour irreversibly when exposed to heat over time.
    • Healthcare providers use this visual indicator to assess if a vaccine has been exposed to inappropriate temperatures.
  • Usage Criteria:
    • The vaccine is usable if the inner square of the VVM is lighter than the outer circle. (Option B)
    • The vaccine should be discarded if the inner square is the same colour as or darker than the outer circle.

questions.text: All are live vaccines except:
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a live vaccine.

Live vaccines contain attenuated (weakened) pathogens that induce a strong immune response.

Rotavirus, Measles, and Varicella vaccines are all live attenuated vaccines.

Hepatitis B vaccine contains HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) and is inactivated.

 

Live vs. Inactivated Vaccines

Vaccines can be classified into live attenuated vaccines and inactivated vaccines based on their mechanism of inducing immunity.

Live Attenuated Vaccines (LAVs)

  • Contain weakened versions of the pathogen.
  • Provide strong, long-lasting immunity with fewer doses.
  • Not given to immunocompromised individuals due to risk of reactivation.

Examples of Live Vaccines:

Vaccine

Disease Prevented

Rotavirus

Rotavirus gastroenteritis

Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR)

Measles, Mumps, Rubella

Varicella

Chickenpox

Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV)

Poliomyelitis

Yellow Fever

Yellow Fever

BCG

Tuberculosis

Inactivated Vaccines

  • Contain killed or non-infectious components of the pathogen.
  • Require booster doses for sustained immunity.
  • Safer for immunocompromised patients.

Examples of Inactivated Vaccines:

Vaccine

Disease Prevented

Type

Hepatitis B

Hepatitis B

Recombinant subunit

Polio (IPV)

Poliomyelitis

Inactivated

Rabies

Rabies

Inactivated

Influenza (Injectable)

Influenza

Inactivated

COVID-19 (Covaxin, Sinopharm)

COVID-19

Inactivated

 

Rotavirus (Option A): Incorrect because it is a live oral vaccine used to prevent severe rotavirus diarrhea.

 

Measles (Option C): Incorrect because it is part of the MMR vaccine, which is live attenuated.

 

Varicella (Option D): Incorrect because it is a live attenuated vaccine used to prevent chickenpox.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding rabies immunoglobulin?

choices.text: It is exclusively given only in the deltoid
If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option A)

Explanation

 

RIG is not exclusively given in the deltoid. It is administered by infiltrating as much of the dose as possible around and into the wound site, with the remaining dose injected intramuscularly (usually in the gluteal region). It should not be given in the deltoid or gluteal region alone without infiltrating the wound.

 

The dose is 20 IU/kg (Option B) is true for human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG). For equine RIG (ERIG), the dose is 40 IU/kg.

 

Administer it immediately after exposure (Option C) is true. RIG should be given as soon as possible after exposure, especially in Category III wounds, to neutralise the virus at the site of entry.

 

If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred (Option D) is true. ERIG is used when HRIG is unavailable, and it is equally effective when administered correctly.

questions.text: Shanchol vaccine consists of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bivalent 2 doses:

  • This refers to a vaccine that targets two different strains of Vibrio cholerae and requires two doses for complete immunization. The Shanchol vaccine is a bivalent vaccine, meaning it covers two different strains of Vibrio cholerae (O1 and O139) and typically requires two doses for full protection.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine is kept at lowest level?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - OPV:

  • The OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is kept at the lowest level in Intermediate-Level Refrigerators (ILRs) compared to the other vaccines listed.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): DPT is a combination vaccine and is sensitive to temperature changes. It needs to be stored in a controlled environment to maintain its efficacy, typically at a temperature range of 2°C to 8°C in ILRs.

Option C - Hep B (Hepatitis B Vaccine): Hepatitis B vaccine is sensitive to temperature and must be kept at a stable temperature of 2°C to 8°C, similar to DPT, but it is more sensitive to freezing. Thus, it requires careful monitoring to avoid freezing.

Option D - Rota (Rotavirus Vaccine): The Rotavirus vaccine is sensitive to temperature fluctuations and is generally stored in ILRs at 2°C to 8°C. However, it is often kept at a higher level in the cold chain to ensure stability.

questions.text: When are the three doses of fIPV ideally given as per the National Immunization Schedule?

choices.text: 3 doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 completed months
At 10 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 completed months
At 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 18 completed months
3 doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 18 completed months

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 3 doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 completed months

Explanation:

  • IPV ( Inactivated Polio vaccine) is administered by intramuscular or fractional dose by intradermal injection
  • Schedule of fIPV (fractional IPV): 6 and 14 weeks; 0.1 ml ID Right upper arm.
    fIPV: 1/5th of the full dose.
  • From 1 January 2023, the third dose of IPV is introduced into the NIS, which is administered at 9 completed months of age: 0.1 ml ID Left upper arm (as the MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm).

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect

questions.text: A 10 year old child is brought to the clinic for his regular immunization. What vaccine is given as a part of the national immunization schedule?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) TT/Td

Explanation:

  • TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus-diphtheria) vaccine is given as a part of the immunization program for a 10-year-old school child.
  • TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus-diphtheria) vaccine: The TT/Td vaccine is given to provide protection against tetanus and diphtheria. It is often administered as a booster dose every 10 years to maintain immunity. At the age of 10, a child may receive a TT/Td vaccine as a part of their routine immunization schedule.

National Immunization Schedule:

Time

Vaccines

At birth

BCG, OPV0 (OPV birth dose), Hep B (birth dose)

6 weeks

OPV1, Penta1, RVV1, fIPV1, PCV1

10 weeks

OPV2, Penta2, RVV2

14 weeks

OPV3, Penta3, RVV3, fIPV2, PCV2

9 completed months

MR1, JE1, PCV booster, fIPV3, vitamin A

16-24 months

MR2, JE2, OPV booster, DPT booster 1

5-6 years

DPT booster 2

10 years

Td

16 years

Td

Incorrect Options:

BCG (Option B): The BCG vaccine is typically given at birth or during infancy to protect against tuberculosis. It is not part of the immunization program for a 10-year-old child.

MMR (Option C): The MMR vaccine is usually administered around 12-15 months of age and a second dose at 4-6 years of age. It protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. By the age of 10, most children would have already received the recommended doses of the MMR vaccine.

DTP (Option D): The DPT vaccine is typically given during infancy and early childhood to protect against diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough), and tetanus. By the age of 10, children would have already completed the recommended doses of the DPT vaccine series.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a polysaccharide vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hep B:

  • Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant protein vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine.
  • It contains HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) produced through recombinant DNA technology.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: They are examples of polysaccharide vaccines.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the rotavirus vaccine is incorrect?

choices.text: Cannot be given after 6 months of age
It has monovalent and pentavalent form

questions.solution:
Option B - Cannot be given after 6 months of age:

  • Incorrect: This statement is not accurate. The rotavirus vaccine is typically given in multiple doses, starting at around 2 months of age. The series is usually completed by 8 months of age. While the first dose should not be given after 15 weeks of age, the series can and should be completed by 8 months. The recommendation is to complete the vaccination series by 8 months of age.

Incorrect Options:

Correct Option A - Given orally :

  • True: The rotavirus vaccine is administered orally. It is designed to immunize the gastrointestinal tract directly, which is the site of rotavirus infection.

Option C - Live vaccine:

  • True: The rotavirus vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine. It contains a weakened form of the virus that stimulates the immune system without causing disease in healthy individuals.

Option D - It has monovalent and pentavalent form:

  • True: There are two types of rotavirus vaccines available: the monovalent vaccine (Rotarix) and the pentavalent vaccine (RotaTeq). Rotarix contains one strain of the rotavirus, while RotaTeq contains five different strains.

questions.text: A 10-week-old baby has come for vaccination. The baby has had a previous history of inconsolable crying and fever (40 degrees C) after vaccination at 6 weeks. What should be the next step now?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Give DPT

Explanation:

  • Assess if symptoms were directly related to vaccine
  • Contraindications to pertussis vaccine: anaphylaxis, encephalopathy, family history of CNS disorders, concurrent febrile illness
  • Baby's symptoms are likely vaccine-related, no contraindications present
  • Proceeding with DPT vaccination recommended

questions.text: What is the schedule and route of administration of MR vaccine and vitamin A?

choices.text: MR vaccine administered subcutaneously along with oral vitamin A at 8 months
MR vaccine administered intramuscularly along oral vitamin A at 8 months
MR vaccine administered subcutaneously along with oral vitamin A at 9 months
MR vaccine administered intramuscularly along with oral vitamin A at 9 months

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) MR vaccine administered subcutaneously along with oral vitamin A at 9 months

Explanation:

National Immunization Schedule:

BCG, OPV0 (OPV birth dose), Hep B (birth dose)

OPV1, Penta1, RVV1, fIPV1, PCV1

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Td vaccine

Explanation:

  • TT/Td vaccine given at 10 years in school program
  • Pentavalent vaccine given at 6, 10, 14 weeks with boosters
  • TT boosters at 10, 16 years
  • Prevents Tetanus from Clostridium tetani
  • Tetanospasmin is dangerous exotoxin
  • Soil is source
  • Herd immunity ineffective

 

National Immunization Schedule:

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate approach to managing a young male patient who has presented at the hospital with a clean-cut wound that is not bleeding, and who received a complete tetanus vaccination 10 years ago?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

Explanation:

  • Single-dose tetanus toxoid needed for clean cut wound with previous booster within 10 years
  • Thorough wound cleaning advised, removal of foreign bodies

Tetanus Management Protocol:

Category

Clean wound

Unclean wound

Category A

Has had a complete course of toxoid or a booster dose (full immunisation) within the past 5 years.

Only wound care.

Only wound care.

Full immunization > 5 years

ago < 10 years.

Wound Care + TT single dose.

Wound Care + TT single dose.

Category C

Full Immunization > 10 years

ago.

Wound Care + TT single dose + Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin.

 

Category D

Unknown, not known, never

taken immunisation.

course.

Wound Care + TT complete

course + Human Tetanus

Immunoglobulin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the fIPV dose schedule under the National Immunization Schedule?

choices.text: At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years

questions.solution:
Fractional Inactivated Polio Vaccine (fIPV) is administered intradermally at 6 weeks and 14 weeks as part of the routine immunisation schedule. Additionally, a booster dose is given at 9 months.

 

Differences between IPV and OPV:

 

Characteristic

IPV (salk type)

OPV (sabin type)

Type of vaccine

Killed formalised virus

Live attenuated virus

Mode of administration

S/C or IM (0.5 mL)

Oral (2 drops)

Type of immunity

Only humoral

Humoral and intestinal

Prevention of

Paralysis

Paralysis + Intestinal re-infection

Control of epidemics

Not useful

Effective

Storage & transport

Less stringent conditions

Requires sub-zero temperatures

Shelf life

Longer

Short

VAPP (Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio)

Zero incidences

1 per 1 million vaccines

 

  • Schedule of OPV: 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years; 2 oral drops
  • Schedule of fIPV (fractional IPV): 6 and 14 weeks; 0.1 ml ID Right upper arm.
    fIPV: 1/5th of the full dose.
  • From 1 January 2023, the third dose of IPV is introduced into the NIS, which is administered at 9 completed months of age: 0.1 ml ID Left upper arm (as the MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm).

 

6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks (Option A) is incorrect because fIPV is given at 6 and 14 weeks, not at 10 weeks.

At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years (Option B) is incorrect because this schedule includes OPV doses and does not match the fIPV schedule, which is 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and a booster at 9 months.

6 weeks, 10 weeks, 12 weeks (Option D) is incorrect because fIPV is not given at 10 and 12 weeks. The correct schedule is 6 weeks and 14 weeks, with a booster at 9 months.

questions.text: Which of the following is the schedule of the OPV vaccine?
questions.solution:
Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is administered as part of the routine immunisation schedule at 6, 10, and 14 weeks along with DPT and other vaccines. Additionally, a booster dose is given at 16–24 months.

 

Differences between IPV and OPV:

 

Characteristic

IPV (salk type)

OPV (sabin type)

Type of vaccine

Killed formalised virus

Live attenuated virus

Mode of administration

S/C or IM (0.5 mL)

Oral (2 drops)

Type of immunity

Only humoral

Humoral and intestinal

Prevention of

Paralysis

Paralysis + Intestinal re-infection

Control of epidemics

Not useful

Effective

Storage & transport

Less stringent conditions

Requires sub-zero temperatures

Shelf life

Longer

Short

VAPP (Vaccine Associated Paralytic Polio)

Zero incidences

1 per 1 million vaccines

 

  • Schedule of OPV: 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years; 2 oral drops
  • Schedule of fIPV (fractional IPV): 6 and 14 weeks; 0.1 ml ID Right upper arm.
    fIPV: 1/5th of the full dose.
  • From 1 January 2023, the third dose of IPV is introduced into the NIS, which is administered at 9 completed months of age: 0.1 ml ID Left upper arm (as the MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm).

questions.text: BCG vaccine provides protection against which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - CNS and disseminated TB:

  • BCG vaccine is most effective against CNS (Central Nervous System) TB and disseminated TB.
  • It primarily prevents severe forms of TB in infants and young children.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pulmonary TB.

Option C - Pulmonary and CNS TB.

Option D - Pulmonary and skeletal T.

questions.text: In the laboratory, a microbiologist is preparing the BCG vaccine. Which of the following substances is used as a diluent for the BCG vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Normal saline:

  • Used as a diluent to reconstitute the BCG vaccine
  • Solution of sodium chloride in water with the same concentration as body fluids
  • Ensures proper mixing of the vaccine powder or freeze-dried formulation

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Distilled water: Less commonly used for vaccine dilution

Option C - Dextrose: Not typically used for BCG vaccine dilution

Option D - Colloids: Not commonly used as diluents for vaccines

questions.text: Which of the following is a heat-sensitive indicator of vaccine viability?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vaccine vial monitor:

  • Heat-sensitive indicator affixed to vaccine vials or packages
  • Provides visual indication of excessive heat exposure
  • Helps determine vaccine viability and safety

Incorrect Options:

Option A - e-VIN: Real-time monitoring system for vaccine stocks and temperatures, not heat-sensitive indicator

Option B - Freeze indicator: Indicates exposure to freezing temperatures, not vaccine viability or heat exposure

Option D - Fridge indicator: Monitors refrigerator temperature for vaccine storage, not specifically a heat-sensitive indicator

questions.text: Which test is employed to assess freeze-induced damage in vaccines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Shake test:

  • Used to check for freeze damage in vaccines
  • Involves gently shaking the vaccine vial to observe clumping or visible particles
  • Indicates potential damage due to freezing

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Schick test: Determines immunity to diphtheria

Option C - Habel test: No commonly known test in vaccine context

Option D - Tine test: Determines immune response to tuberculin antigen for TB diagnosis

questions.text: As per the national immunization schedule, which vaccines are indicated at the first visit for immunization of a 13-month-old baby who has not been previously immunized?

choices.text: BCG, OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Rota virus 1st dose
OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Measles 1st dose
OPV 1st dose, DPT 1st dose, Measles 1st dose

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - OPV 1st dose, DPT 1st dose, Measles 1st dose:

  • OPV 1st dose: Protects against polio, administered at this visit
  • DPT 1st dose: Protects against diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus, usually given at this visit
  • Measles 1st dose: Provides immunity against measles, typically given at 9-12 months but can be given at 13-month visit if missed

Incorrect Options:

Option A - BCG, OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Rotavirus 1st dose: BCG can't be given after 1 year

Option B - OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Measles 1st dose: Pentavalent can't be given after 1 year

Option C - BCG, OPV 1st dose, Measles 1st dose: BCG can't be given after 1 year

questions.text: A polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae has 23 serotypes. In which of the following patients is this vaccine most beneficial ?

choices.text: A patient with sickle cell disease
A patient with recurrent otitis media

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sickle cell disease:

  • Sickle cell patients are prone to severe infections due to spleen issues.
  • Recommended to prevent pneumococcal infections with the 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A child < 2 years: Children under 2 already receive routine pneumococcal vaccination.

Option C - A patient with cystic fibrosis: Polysaccharide vaccine may not be optimal for immunocompromised patients like those with cystic fibrosis.

Option D - Option D: A patient with recurrent otitis media: Polysaccharide vaccine may not target specific serotypes causing otitis media.

questions.text: What would be the appropriate treatment for a 5-year-old boy who had received a complete course of rabies vaccine in December 2018, but was bitten on the toe by his fully vaccinated pet dog in November 2019, resulting in bleeding at the bite site?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2 doses of vaccine on Day 0 & 3:

  • The boy and the dog have a history of rabies vaccination, lowering the risk of transmission.
  • Administering 2 doses of rabies vaccine on Day 0 and Day 3 provides additional protection and covers potential immunity gaps.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No treatment: No treatment may leave gaps in protection despite previous vaccinations.

Option C - 5 doses of vaccine with Immunoglobulin: Immunoglobulin is unnecessary as the dog is fully vaccinated.

Option D - 5 doses of vaccine: 5 doses are excessive given the circumstances.

questions.text: At a PHC, vaccine storage is done in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR):

  • ILRs are designed for storing vaccines and medications.
  • They maintain stable temperature ranges required for vaccine storage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vaccine carrier: Used for transporting vaccines, not long-term storage.

Option C - Walk-in Cold rooms: Large refrigerated spaces, not typically found at PHCs.

Option D - Ice packs: Provide temporary cooling during transportation, not long-term storage.

questions.text: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4 weeks:

  • Minimum interval between two live vaccines is 4 weeks
  • Live vaccines contain weakened forms of infectious agents
  • Stimulate immune system without causing full-blown illness
  • Interval ensures adequate immune response, minimizes interference

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2 weeks: Shorter interval may not allow sufficient time for immune response

Option C - 8 weeks: Longer interval may not be necessary, recommended minimum is shorter

Option D - 12 weeks: Even longer interval generally not required for most live vaccines

questions.text: Which vaccine among the options provided is not recommended during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Varicella (Chickenpox) vaccine:

  • Contraindicated during pregnancy
  • Contains live attenuated virus, theoretical risk to developing fetus
  • Not recommended for pregnant women
  • Administered before pregnancy or after delivery if woman is not immune to chickenpox

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hepatitis A vaccine: Hepatitis A vaccine safe during pregnancy, recommended for at-risk women

Option B - Hepatitis B vaccine: Hepatitis B vaccine safe during pregnancy, recommended for all pregnant women

Option C - Rabies vaccine: Rabies vaccine not contraindicated during pregnancy, benefits may outweigh risks in certain situations

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child developed with sore throat, difficulty in swallowing, and mild fever. On examination, the clinical picture shown below is seen. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: It is administered on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.
A history of anaphylaxis with same vaccineis not a contraindication
The cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A history of anaphylaxis with the same vaccine is not a contraindication:

  • False statement, history of anaphylaxis is a contraindication

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is administered on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh: Administered on anterolateral aspect of thigh, correct site for vaccine administration

Option C - The cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7 years of age: Cellular pertussis component not recommended after 7 years of age, true statement

Option D - The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose: Diphtheria toxoid dose in adults may be lower than pediatric dose, true statement

questions.text: BCG is diluted with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Normal saline::

  • BCG vaccine is typically reconstituted with normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride solution) before administration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Distilled water: Lacks necessary electrolytes for vaccine viability.

Option C - Ringer lactate: Not standard for BCG vaccine reconstitution.

Option D - Distilled water (mentioned twice in the options): Insufficient for maintaining vaccine viability.

questions.text: How long is the protection provided by the Yellow fever vaccine considered valid for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Life long:

  • Yellow fever vaccine provides lifelong protection against yellow fever.

Incorrect options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: In which of the following outbreaks is mass vaccination considered to be the most effective?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Polio:

  • Mass vaccination is most effective for diseases preventable through vaccination and with high vaccine coverage achievable.
  • Polio is highly infectious, especially in children, but can be prevented through vaccination.
  • Mass vaccination campaigns for polio aim for high vaccine coverage to interrupt transmission and protect susceptible individuals.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cholera: Controlled through other measures like water and sanitation improvements.

Option B - Typhoid: Usually targeted at high-risk groups, not mass campaigns.

Option D - Whooping cough: prevented by vaccination but not typically through mass campaigns.

questions.text: In how many days should the post exposure Measles vaccine be given?
questions.solution:
Incorrect Option B - Within 3 days:

  • Incubation period for measles is 10-14 days.
  • 10th day- fever stars
  • 14th day -rashes start
  • IP of vaccine-induced measles is 7 days.
  • Post-exposure vaccine must be used with in 3 days of exposure

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D

questions.text: At what age is the first dose of hepatitis B vaccine given?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - At Birth:

  • First dose of hepatitis B vaccine: Administered within 24 hours of birth
  • Provides timely protection against transmission from mother to baby
  • Subsequent doses: At 1-2 months and 6 months of age to complete the series
  • Recommended as routine childhood vaccination by WHO and CDC

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 6 weeks: Safe to administer at 6 weeks but recommended to complete series as soon as possible

Option C - 10 weeks: 10 weeks would be too long a delay

Option D - 6 months: Vaccine is safe and effective after 6 months, but recommended to administer as early as possible, ideally within 24 hours of birth

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines are given at birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - BCG, OPV, Hepatitis B:

  • BCG, OPV, and Hepatitis B vaccines given at birth in many countries
  • BCG: Tuberculosis protection
  • OPV: Polio protection
  • Hepatitis B vaccine: Protects against Hepatitis B
  • Administered within 24 hours of birth

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pentavalent, MR, HiB: Pentavalent, MR, and HiB not given at birth

Option B - BCG, OPV, MR: MR vaccine given at 9 months, not at birth

Option D - BCG, IP, Hepatitis B: IP vaccine usually given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks, not at birth
